text:
Anyone has paid for the Substack custom domain? What has your experience been like post purchase? I have a few questions:
• Did your SEO improve?
• Does the 'substack' logo get removed at the bottom of the email newsletter get sent when you have a custom domain?
• Did the email address still have 'substack' mentioned?

elements.text: Anyone has paid for the Substack custom domain? What has your experience been like post purchase? I have a few questions:
Does the 'substack' logo get removed at the bottom of the email newsletter get sent when you have a custom domain?
Did the email address still have 'substack' mentioned?

text: Personally, I'd never build in somebody else's playground. This happened with Medium as well.

elements.text: Personally, I'd never build in somebody else's playground. This happened with Medium as well.

text: yeah, but their email service is free, so thought I'll go ahead with them. But I get your point as well. Will think through again on this.

elements.text: yeah, but their email service is free, so thought I'll go ahead with them. But I get your point as well. Will think through again on this.

text:
I am quite unhappy with the Substack SEO and have moved away from it. Very interested to hear if SEO improves if you get the custom domain option.

Still... my 6-12m on experience on Substack has led me to the same conclusion as <@UUXMCJQ15>. Wish I knew this earlier :smile:

elements.text:

Still... my 6-12m on experience on Substack has led me to the same conclusion as

text: Their email is free but they're pushing everybody to their new app where, as you might expect, people that subscribe to you do not automatically get emails. They get notified in the app. The walls are going up around their garden.

elements.text: Their email is free but they're pushing everybody to their new app where, as you might expect, people that subscribe to you do not automatically get emails. They get notified in the app. The walls are going up around their garden.

text:
This is a bit of an unusual project and I’m reaching out too see whether anyone have dealt with this.

At an education company we’ve started with a Partnership model with Universities which is really taking off.
Our base is D2C education where I focused heavily on content marketing and it’s been paying off.

Now I’m tasked to come up with a plan that will bring organic traffic to these University websites as well.
Uni partners have agreed to use our pages in their subdomains so our DA and UR rating is going to be suuuuper juicy.

But the problem is that I have to come up with a content that is scalable throughout 5+ (and counting) Uni partners and we’re in an industry where search volume isn’t that big yet. And since DA of Uni’s is so big we’ll probably cannibalize our own D2C content if I go after Thus looking for your recommendation.

Here’s what I’m thinking so far:

> Identify best performing pieces of information on our d2c and try to localize it on a GEO where University is operating. (i.e. best metaverse jobs in California)
> Rewrite best performing pieces in the shorter articles but target long tail kws (sounds interesting but how do I do that 5x+ times). Does Google take into an account localization and offers SERPs based on geo?
> should I target non-industry content like history of the University to get traffic? however I could do “metaverse” expert from [Uni/City] (seems non-contextual so not a fan of this)

With this I’d invest in backlinking services and distribute backlinks to each of these partners.
